values.description:
This pull request adds a brief quickstart tutorial for sdformat newcomers. It features a small utility that parses and prints details of a given arbitrary SDF, with a code breakdown explaining it. 

cc @andres_fortier @agalbachicar to track progress.
values.title: Add quickstart tutorial

summary.raw:
This pull request adds a brief quickstart tutorial for sdformat newcomers. It features a small utility that parses and prints details of a given arbitrary SDF, with a code breakdown explaining it. 

cc @andres_fortier @agalbachicar to track progress.
summary.html:
This pull request adds a brief quickstart tutorial for sdformat newcomers. It features a small utility that parses and prints details of a given arbitrary SDF, with a code breakdown explaining it.

cc @andres_fortier @agalbachicar to track progress.

values.description: This tutorial will eventually include proposals for the semantics of describing pose frames, but I started with a description of existing legacy behavior, and it was getting decently long, so I thought I would submit it for review first before starting with proposals for new behavior.
values.title: Pose frame semantics: describe legacy behavior

values.description: These are suggested changes to pull request #5. This is mainly to change the order of frames in notations, per our discussion with @scpeters. I also added more sentences to explain our notation in the Specifying Pose tutorial.

values.description:
There were several comment threads not addressed in pull request #5 that are addressed here:

full comment threads from pr #5: #!/osrf/sdf_tutorials/pull-requests/5/pose-frame-semantics-describe-legacy/activity#

preview: http://sdformat.org/tutorials?branch=legacy_pose_frame_followup

* fix invalid link

* add URDF comments near <origin> snippets

* add inline comments to examples of valid and invalid naming

* recommend not to use world as a link name

* add more inline comments about valid and invalid examples

* combine TODO into note about future discussions

* scope suffix notation to kinematic quantities since inertial quantities are more complicated

* refer to specify_pose tutorial before using fancy notation

* fix typo

* use relative /tutorials in links instead of full URL to allow for local hosting

* use relative URL to link to tutorial
values.title: Follow-up to comments made in pull request #5

values.description:
As @amcastro0622 discussed in a [drake pull request](https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/pull/11230#pullrequestreview-226214442), it is better to use the body-fixed joint frames `Jp` and `Jc` than the ambiguous joint frame `J`. This pull request modifies the text of the kinematics tutorial and one figure to use `Jp` and `Jc` exclusively.

Preview: 
http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=spec_model_kinematics&cat=specification&branch=kinematics_Jp_Jc

Further work is to illustrate the `Jc` and `Jp` frames in the [last figure](#!/osrf/sdf_tutorials/src/eda3d865c05f36cbe29add616d36fec17dab7a93/spec_model_kinematics/revolute_joint_1b.svg?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default) of the tutorial.
values.title: Replace joint frame references with Jc and Jp

summary.raw:
As @amcastro0622 discussed in a [drake pull request](https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/pull/11230#pullrequestreview-226214442), it is better to use the body-fixed joint frames `Jp` and `Jc` than the ambiguous joint frame `J`. This pull request modifies the text of the kinematics tutorial and one figure to use `Jp` and `Jc` exclusively.

Preview: 
http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=spec_model_kinematics&cat=specification&branch=kinematics_Jp_Jc

Further work is to illustrate the `Jc` and `Jp` frames in the [last figure](#!/osrf/sdf_tutorials/src/eda3d865c05f36cbe29add616d36fec17dab7a93/spec_model_kinematics/revolute_joint_1b.svg?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default) of the tutorial.
summary.html:
As @amcastro0622 discussed in a drake pull request, it is better to use the body-fixed joint frames Jp and Jc than the ambiguous joint frame J. This pull request modifies the text of the kinematics tutorial and one figure to use Jp and Jc exclusively.

Preview: http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=spec_model_kinematics&cat=specification&branch=kinematics_Jp_Jc

Further work is to illustrate the Jc and Jp frames in the last figure of the tutorial.

values.description:
This adds sections to the Legacy Pose Frame Semantics documentation describing ideal parsing stages for sdf 1.4 and 1.5 models. Note that libsdformat and gazebo don't actually do many of these checks and will happily load files with links/collisions with duplicate names. It may give more error messages and may behave unpredictably (which "link" would be attached to a joint if one of the duplicates was specified), but it certainly doesn't fail hard at all. I'm not sure if we want to reflect that in the text anywhere.

Preview: http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics&branch=parsing_stages
values.title: List parsing stages for sdf 1.4 and 1.5 models

values.description: The main change here is to document the parsing states for the proposed pose frame semantics, highlighting the differences with the legacy behavior using italics. I've also included two small changes in 8701b60 and b213344 that change the target version of the SDF spec to 1.7 (instead of 2.0) and also refers to some links as documentation rather than tutorials.
values.title: Parsing stages for proposed pose behavior

summary.raw: The main change here is to document the parsing states for the proposed pose frame semantics, highlighting the differences with the legacy behavior using italics. I've also included two small changes in 8701b60 and b213344 that change the target version of the SDF spec to 1.7 (instead of 2.0) and also refers to some links as documentation rather than tutorials.
summary.html: The main change here is to document the parsing states for the proposed pose frame semantics, highlighting the differences with the legacy behavior using italics. I've also included two small changes in 8701b60 and b213344 that change the target version of the SDF spec to 1.7 (instead of 2.0) and also refers to some links as documentation rather than tutorials.

values.title: Hand full of typos and tutorial references from across the doc

values.description:
While working on the code implementation, I realized that lights can be declared in the world as `//world/light`, and I think they should have implicit frames and be handled in a similar manner to `//world/model`.

@{5d15084bf46aa30c271ca029} I hope this doesn't derail your revisions. We can wait and merge it after you've finished the outline if that makes it easier.
values.title: Add //world/light to the sdf parsing stages and proposal as a sibling of //world/model

summary.raw:
While working on the code implementation, I realized that lights can be declared in the world as `//world/light`, and I think they should have implicit frames and be handled in a similar manner to `//world/model`.

@{5d15084bf46aa30c271ca029} I hope this doesn't derail your revisions. We can wait and merge it after you've finished the outline if that makes it easier.
summary.html:
While working on the code implementation, I realized that lights can be declared in the world as //world/light, and I think they should have implicit frames and be handled in a similar manner to //world/model.

@MaryaB I hope this doesn't derail your revisions. We can wait and merge it after you've finished the outline if that makes it easier.

values.description:
This adds a section to the proposal that discusses scoping rules for referencing frames by name  in the world scope and model scope. It also explicitly allows every `//pose` to use `//pose[@relative_to]` in the appropriate scope, even if the objects are not sibling elements. I've updated the parsing stages and copied a bit of the example from pull request #16 and discussed the `//link/frame` idea as an alternative considered.

I've targeted this at pull request #33 to avoid conflicts in the changes to the parsing stages.

This pull request is an alternative to pull request #16 and pull request #31.

Preview: http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics_proposal&branch=frame_scoping_rules
values.title: Proposal: scoping rules, allow everything to use //pose[@relative_to]

summary.raw:
This adds a section to the proposal that discusses scoping rules for referencing frames by name  in the world scope and model scope. It also explicitly allows every `//pose` to use `//pose[@relative_to]` in the appropriate scope, even if the objects are not sibling elements. I've updated the parsing stages and copied a bit of the example from pull request #16 and discussed the `//link/frame` idea as an alternative considered.

I've targeted this at pull request #33 to avoid conflicts in the changes to the parsing stages.

This pull request is an alternative to pull request #16 and pull request #31.

Preview: http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics_proposal&branch=frame_scoping_rules
summary.html:
This adds a section to the proposal that discusses scoping rules for referencing frames by name in the world scope and model scope. It also explicitly allows every //pose to use //pose[@relative_to] in the appropriate scope, even if the objects are not sibling elements. I've updated the parsing stages and copied a bit of the example from pull request #16 and discussed the //link/frame idea as an alternative considered.

I've targeted this at pull request #33 to avoid conflicts in the changes to the parsing stages.

This pull request is an alternative to pull request #16 and pull request #31.

values.description:
Couple things in particular that need looking at:

I moved “Empty //pose and //frame elements imply identity pose” to the “Terminology” section \(1.3\). It was in the “New semantics” section \(now “Name conflicts and scoping rules…“\), and before that the “Model frame and canonical link” section.

Section 3.1, “Scoping rules for referencing frames by name“, is new and doesn’t have any info on previous versions or reasoning.

There’s a few places that would benefit from linking to other sections in the doc, but it seems like markdown doesn’t allow that? Anyone know?

[http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose\_frame\_semantics\_proposal&cat=pose\_semantics\_docs&branch=pose\_frame\_proposal\_redo](http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics_proposal&cat=pose_semantics_docs&branch=pose_frame_proposal_redo)
values.title: revisions for pose frame proposal

values.description:
I noticed that there is a markdown link to a section on the same page in the Creating Worlds tutorial that looks like `[Appendix](#appendix)`:

* #!/osrf/sdf_tutorials/annotate/default/spec_world/tutorial1.md?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#tutorial1.md-10

It wasn't working quite right because we had a `<a>` tag for the Appendix, but I don't think we need that anymore, so I've removed it.

Preview: http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=spec_world&branch=anchor_link

Look for the link near the top of the page in the following text:

> **Note:** See [Appendix](http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=spec_world&branch=anchor_link#appendix) about a required name attribute of `<world>`
values.title: spec_world: don't need <a> tag for appendix anchor anymore

values.description:
I've been working with xpath a bit recently, and I believe we should be using a slightly different syntax in our proposal to refer to xml attributes. Currently we use `//element[@attribute]`, but I think it makes more sense as `//element/@attribute`, since the latter refers to the attribute, while the former is more often used to help select a subset of elements like `//element[@attribute='1']`.

See the xpath spec for examples of expected usage:

* https://www.w3.org/TR/1999/REC-xpath-19991116/#path-abbrev

So I converted all the instances that I could find and have targeted this to pull request #40.
values.title: Use //element/@attribute to refer to attributes instead of //element[@attribute]

summary.raw:
I've been working with xpath a bit recently, and I believe we should be using a slightly different syntax in our proposal to refer to xml attributes. Currently we use `//element[@attribute]`, but I think it makes more sense as `//element/@attribute`, since the latter refers to the attribute, while the former is more often used to help select a subset of elements like `//element[@attribute='1']`.

See the xpath spec for examples of expected usage:

* https://www.w3.org/TR/1999/REC-xpath-19991116/#path-abbrev

So I converted all the instances that I could find and have targeted this to pull request #40.
summary.html:
I've been working with xpath a bit recently, and I believe we should be using a slightly different syntax in our proposal to refer to xml attributes. Currently we use //element[@attribute], but I think it makes more sense as //element/@attribute, since the latter refers to the attribute, while the former is more often used to help select a subset of elements like //element[@attribute='1'].

See the xpath spec for examples of expected usage:

  • https://www.w3.org/TR/1999/REC-xpath-19991116/#path-abbrev

So I converted all the instances that I could find and have targeted this to pull request #40.

values.description: There are several places where people have been using static models without any links, which is now not allowed with sdf 1.7. It occurs to me that the implicit model frame of a static model can be attached to the world, so I think we don't need to require those static models to have links.
values.title: Allow static models without links

summary.raw: There are several places where people have been using static models without any links, which is now not allowed with sdf 1.7. It occurs to me that the implicit model frame of a static model can be attached to the world, so I think we don't need to require those static models to have links.
